comments.body:
Note -- the sh.py version of this does not handle multiple path elements.  The calling function must have reduced it to a single directory/filename.  So when the calling function gives you good values they'd be "~" or "~username".  If the calling function were to give the sh.py module any other value it will return a command that will return the string itself.

I don't know if that matters since your comment says that powershell already differs due to not being able to handle ~username but thought I'd mention it.

In my test below (https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/9688/files#diff-f9c7ca43474a10fad9eac81b060d8a95R148) I end up getting the full path because backslashes get used as the path separator instead of forward slashes. If it starts with ~\ I handle it as a special case of a path relative to the home directory, otherwise it is just returned verbatim.
